newsitem.title: UK: Iran emerges as a mystery big buyer in world wheat.
newsitem.headline: Iran emerges as a mystery big buyer in world wheat.

text.p: Iran is emerging as the world's biggest importer of wheat in the current year, according to figures from the International Grains Council on Thursday

The London-based IGC, an authoritative monitor of supply/demand trends in world grain, saw Iran importing 6.6 million tonnes of wheat and flour in the 12 months to June 30, 1997 - ahead of Egypt on 6.2 and Japan at 6.0 million tonnes.
The forecast for Iran in the latest IGC monthly report was sharply up from an estimate of 5.0 million tonnes a month ago and from the estimated total for 1995-96 of 3.0 million.
The IGC offered no explanation. Grain traders say the surge is something of a mystery but believe that much of the wheat is for re-export elsewhere in central Asia after poor harvests there.
The rise in demand from Iran is offset by the lower Chinese imports after good crops in China.
The IGC retained an estimate of the total 1996 world wheat crop at a bumper 580 million tonnes, up from a drought-hit 1995 total of 540 million tonnes.
And it forecast 1997 as only just lower, at 578 million.
Its report was issued against a backdrop of renewed concern about high grain prices, at a time when world stocks are around the lowest in 20 years.

Wheat prices "spiked" to historic highs in Chicago grain pits at $7.50 per bushel early in 1996. After flood and freeze in North America and a prolonged dry spell in Europe, some analysts see a risk that importers will again be paying inflated food bills.
Chicago wheat traded at $4.50 in April, up from $3.80 at the end of 1996, and the European Union has reimposed a tax on exports to keep a lid on its internal prices.
